results.headline: A Hero of Hockey
results.display_title: Prince Brat and the Whipping Boy

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Prince Brat and the Whipping Boy

results.summary_short: “The Rocket” is a polished, costumed production, with lots of heavy music, fedoras and trains hurtling through the wintry Quebec landscape.

results.headline: Men Behaving Extremely, With True Believers’ Passion

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Protagonist

results.summary_short: “Protagonist” is an enthralling documentary exploration of people with obsessive needs for control and self-mastery.

results.headline: Haunted History

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Oswald's Ghost

results.summary_short: The documentary “Oswald’s Ghost” initially plays as yet another primer on the assassination of John F. Kennedy and the vilification of Lee Harvey Oswald.

results.headline: Food and Fun

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Nina's Heavenly Delights

results.summary_short: A cloying blend of Bollywood sentiment and “Amélie” whimsy, “Nina’s Heavenly Delights” is a lesbian-foodie fairy tale that keeps its appetites well under control.

results.headline: A Soccer Player’s Ordeal in an Argentine Prison

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Chronicle of an Escape

results.summary_short: It is a small relief to discover that “Chronicle of an Escape” is relatively restrained in its depiction of torture. Despite its restraint, the movie is deeply unsettling.

results.headline: A War Hero’s Terror, Tragedy and Rescue

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Badland

results.summary_short: The mawkish yet weirdly mesmerizing film “Badland” is independent in scale but aggressively Hollywood in storytelling.

results.headline: Christmas Is Almost Here and Santa Is in Her Sights

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Be My Oswald

results.summary_short: A seriously deranged dramedy about finding yourself through terrorism, “Be My Oswald” attempts high-wire artiness on a bargain-basement budget.

results.headline: Stuck on a Family Hamster Wheel, Mile After Mile, Year After Year

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of The Savages

results.summary_short: Tamara Jenkins’s “The Savages” is a beautifully nuanced tragicomedy about two floundering souls.

results.headline: Back to ‘Don’t Look Back,’ This Time With Dylan’s Songs in the Spotlight

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of 65 Revisited

results.summary_short: The great relief of D. A. Pennebaker’s “65 Revisited” is that this time you can hear Bob Dylan’s songs in their entirety.

results.headline: A Scholarly May and a Literary December Meet in a New York Autumn

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Starting Out in the Evening

results.summary_short: A crepuscular glow suffuses Andrew Wagner’s intelligent, careful adaptation of a near-perfect novel by Brian Morton.

results.headline: Warning: This Worm Wears a Suit

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of He Was a Quiet Man

results.summary_short: Frank Cappello’s film is a surreal creep show with a scatological sense of humor.

results.headline: Surviving Hitch, Welles and Time

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Who Is Norman Lloyd

results.summary_short: It’s hard to know where to begin admiring the subject of “Who Is Norman Lloyd?,” a documentary about the veteran actor, director and producer.

results.headline: A Fallen Plane Is Loaded With Tensions

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Midnight Eagle

results.summary_short: Izuru Narushima’s film is a personal and political melodrama with perfunctory gunplay and explosions.

results.headline: A Cold Look at Warming Mixes Pep and Despair

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Everything's Cool

results.summary_short: Although the underlying outlook of “Everything’s Cool” is dire, the documentary adopts a cheerful comic tone to avoid scaring audiences about global warming.

results.headline: Another Side of Bob Dylan, and Another, and Another ...

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of I'm Not There

results.summary_short: Among its many achievements, Todd Haynes’s “I’m Not There” hurls a Molotov cocktail through the facade of the Hollywood biopic factory.

results.headline: Someday My Prince Will ... Uh, Make That a Manhattan Lawyer

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Enchanted

results.summary_short: “Enchanted” works its magic largely by sending up some of the very stereotypes that have long been Walt Disney Pictures’ profitable stock in trade.

results.headline: Fight to Keep a Language on the Stage

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Yiddish Theater: A Love Story

results.summary_short: Filmed in real time during the freezing winter of 2000, “Yiddish Theater: A Love Story” tracks eight days in the failing life of the Yiddish Public Theater.

results.headline: Something Creepy This Way Creeps, and It Spells Bad News

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of The Mist

results.summary_short: Until the director Frank Darabont decides that he’s saying something important instead of making a nifty horror movie, “The Mist” isn’t half bad.

results.headline: Slaughter on Parade, Without Joystick

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Hitman

results.summary_short: Based on the video game franchise of the same title, “Hitman” exploits every action-flick cliché imaginable and still manages to be dull.

results.headline: Fantasies Without Bounds for a Lothario With Limits
results.display_title: It is Fine! EVERYTHING IS FINE.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of It is Fine! EVERYTHING IS FINE.

results.summary_short: Crispin Hellion Glover’s planned trilogy of blatant weirdness continues with a second installment, “It Is Fine! Everything Is Fine.”
